Umer, I definitely think this question is on topic for the group 
because ultimately it would be interesting to evolve more 
biologically-plausible neural networks with NEAT.  Natural neurons 
are generally much more complicated and more diverse than typical 
ANN's.  For example, natural neurons change their connections 
weights dynamically during activation.  (See our paper on Adaptive 
Neural Networks for a NEAT implementation of this)  Also, natural 
neurons integrate activation over time, rather than working in 
discrete steps.  There are models for doing this in ANN's as well.  

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Umer Iqbal" <umeriqbal81@h...> wrote:
> I haven't studied much biology, so could someone guide me on this 
point?
> We usually make ANNs with neurons that take the weighted some of 
all inputs, apply a function, and give the same result to all its 
outputs.
> Is this the case in nature as well? Is it that simple? or does the 
result vary across different outputs? and does it vary drastically?
> 
> If i've started asking questions outside the scope of this 
discussion group, plz let me know :)
> 
> Regards,
> Umer..
> 
>   ----- Original Message ----- 
>   From: Colin Green 
>   To: neat@yahoogroups.com 
>   Sent: Thursday, June 03, 2004 3:49 AM
>   Subject: Re: [neat] Re: Connections
> 
> 
>   Hi Umer,
> 
>   I agree with John that multiple connections between two given 
neurons 
>   would be redundant. You can still represent the full range of 
values AND 
>   reduce precision at the same time. This is sort of what is 
already done 
>   in Kens NEAT by the using the weight mutation exponent (I think 
that's 
>   what it's called). This effectively defines the size of weight 
>   modifications, a larger weight mutation value gives you less 
possible 
>   values between the minimum and maximum weight, hence reducing 
the search 
>   space. I might be wrong on this one with reagrds to Ken's NEAT, 
but the 
>   idea stands - if you only allow a limited set of values for 
connection 
>   weights you limit the search space. You wouldn't want to limit 
it too 
>   much, otherwise you might not be able to fully explore the 
important 
>   areas of, say, the sigmoid activation function.
> 
>   Colin
> 
>   Umer Iqbal wrote:
> 
>   > Since, natural neural networks work good enough :), couldn't 
>   > decreasing our precision and allowing multiple connections be 
a better 
>   > way of making ANNs?
>   > I dont have any idea how this might be achieved.. but I 
believe that 
>   > the simpler we keep our domain and smaller our search space, 
the 
>   > easier it would be to come up with solutions..
>   > If we could give higher probability of changing weights than 
adding 
>   > new connections, we would in effect be searching in a 
concentrated 
>   > part of the search-space first before moving to higher levels..
>   > That brings me to another idea that I once had: Shouldn't we 
decrease 
>   > the precision of our weights?
>   > Since searching in let's say 15 digits after decimal would be 
many 
>   > times more difficult than searching in 8-10 digits after 
decimal.
>   > And the results would not differ much.
>   > What do the others say?
>   > Can we achieve this somehow?
>   >  
>   > Umer..
>   >  
>   >  
> 
>
